misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No misconception detected (correct algorithm and execution model)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes they must save the last array element, shift elements from right to left to avoid overwriting, then place the saved last element into index 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No gap: this matches Java’s actual array semantics and assignment behavior. The loop iterates from the end toward the front, correctly preventing data loss, and the wrap-around is handled by storing the last element first.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error; produces correct output for the described task (including edge case N=0 and N=1).

evidence.code_snippet: for (a = arraySize - 1; a > 0; a--) { ... userInputArray[a] = c; }

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No detectable misconception (solution is logically correct)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to right-shift an array by 1 with wrap-around, you must (1) save the last element, (2) copy elements from right-to-left so you don’t overwrite needed values, then (3) place the saved last element into index 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No conceptual gap detected. The code correctly models Java array indexing and assignment semantics, and correctly avoids overwrite by iterating from the end down to 1.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None. For N>0 it produces the required right shift with wrap-around; for N=0 it prints an empty shifted array (reasonable behavior).
